repnme.cdata!:
Preparation, adaptation and awareness -
            Kiribati’s climate challenge

abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile focuses on
            preparation, adaption, and awareness of Kiribati’s climate
            challenge. Kiribati was extremely vulnerable to climate
            change and sea level rise. Sea level rise was also
            contaminating groundwater in Tarawa, making it unfit for
            people to drink, increased the potential for epidemics,
            making it difficult to grow crops, and threatened critical
            marine ecosystems. Infant mortality from diarrheal diseases
            in Kiribati was the highest in the Pacific. Kiribati
            Adaptation Program, Phase II (KAP II) supported by the World
            Bank and the Global Environment Facility (GEF) has helped
            identify and pilot adaptation measures to improve coastal
            protection, freshwater supply, and sustainability for the
            Pacific island nation of Kiribati. Climate risk
            considerations have been integrated in key Ministry plans,
            and the project has helped develop and apply best practices
            in water resource management and coastal protection.
            Approximately 0.5 km of sea walls have been built along the
            main road, over 37,000 mangrove seedlings have been planted
            and several water management improvements have been carried
            out, all helping to increase resilience to the effects of
            climate change for Kiribati’s residents.

repnme.cdata!:
Kiribati - Second Adaptation Program (Pilot
            Implementation Phase II) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Adaptation
            Program (Pilot Implementation Phase II) Project for Kiribati
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk
            to global environment outcome was moderate; Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            consistent high-level leadership is crucial to integrating
            climate change adaptation into development processes.
            Effective and timely project implementation depends on
            appropriately skilled individuals and, in particular, a
            strong project manager. Complex procurement arrangements may
            prevent effective implementation progress. Research and
            information generated by a project needs to be consolidated
            and shared. A simple project design with focused scope is
            required to maximize project performance and in-country
            capacity building. Skills gained may be quickly lost if they
            are not regularly applied in regular ministry work.
